https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-27/a-bundesbank-economist-has-a-radical-plan-to-halve-italy-s-debt
Italy’s populist government doesn’t need to ask for money from European partners to halve its debt — it could tap the large private wealth of its citizens, Bundesbank economist Karsten Wendorff suggested.
The radical proposal echoes the debate in Italian media over a potential “wealth tax.” Unlike a tax, however, it wouldn’t directly eat into the patrimony of the country’s families, according to its proponent, who heads the German central bank’s public finance department.
“Instead of a European fund that buys Italian government bonds and that is ultimately backed by European taxpayers, a national fund should be created,” Wendorff wrote in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung Saturday. “This fund would buy Italian government bonds.”
Such a fund would be financed by “national solidarity bonds” that Italian households would be obliged to purchase — for example, to the tune of 20 percent of their net wealth. At such a rate “almost half of Italian government debt could be converted into solidarity bonds.”

Delaying Brexit or forcing a second referendum would be tantamount to undermining democracy, because it would mean that a referendum result would never be accepted unless it gave the establishment the result that it wanted.
It’s one thing for a banana republic, such as Ireland, to force multiple referendums on its people until the government gets the result that it wants, but if one of the world’s most important democracies and geo-political powers (the U.K.) begins to do this then the principle of democracy itself becomes hollowed-out and people will lose faith in the idea of democracy. Also, in a world where there is a struggle between the ideas of democracy and that of oligarchy, the U.K. would not be able to show itself as having true faith in democracy when it matters; this would undermine the case for democracy particularly in the East.

@J. Reid: A major problem for a lot of countries is that they have citizens who either don’t know what they are talking about, or are simply lie to make their point seems valid. We had a referendum on the Lisbon Treaty, which the electorate rejected. The government went back to the EU and sought changes to the parts of the treaty which were unpalatable to Irish voters. These changes were made and we had another referendum, this time on the revised Lisbon Treaty. We voted for it. The government didn’t rig the vote or hold a gun to our heads. WE choose to accept the revised treaty. A country were citizens can effect policy with their votes is not a banana republic, it’s a functioning democracy. The fact that you don’t like the decisions made by your fellow citizens is neither here nor there. It’s the price you pay for living in a democratic society.

“Italy’s populist government doesn’t need to ask for money from European partners to halve its debt — it could tap the large private wealth of its citizens, Bundesbank economist Karsten Wendorff suggested.
The radical proposal echoes the debate in Italian media over a potential “wealth tax.” Unlike a tax, however, it wouldn’t directly eat into the patrimony of the country’s families, according to its proponent, who heads the German central bank’s public finance department.
“Instead of a European fund that buys Italian government bonds and that is ultimately backed by European taxpayers, a national fund should be created,” Wendorff wrote in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung Saturday. “This fund would buy Italian government bonds.”
Such a fund would be financed by “national solidarity bonds” that Italian households would be obliged to purchase — for example, to the tune of 20 percent of their net wealth. At such a rate “almost half of Italian government debt could be converted into solidarity bonds.”

No, it does not have a similar system of government to Scotland in the United Kingdom. Greenland has far, far more independence than Scotland and can negotiate international trade deals (which Scotland can’t). Greenland, the Faroe Islands and Denmark are the three countries which make up the Kingdom of Denmark. Unlike Scotland or Wales, each of these countries can initiate their own independence proceedings. It is entirely feasible, albeit unlikely, that Denmark could become independent of the Kingdom of Denmark, leaving the Kingdom of Denmark comprising solely of Greenland and the Faroe Islands. A closer comparison, though still not accurate, would be the relationship between the UK and the Isle of Man or the Netherlands and Aruba.

@Ian O’Rourke: Also, the Good Friday agreement has been used as an international template for conflict resolution between other countries.
If it’s not upheld, if any country can just rip it up unchallenged and without consequence – what message is that sending out to the other international parties using and abiding by the template and legal framework?

@Ian O’Rourke: unfortunately the Good Friday Agreement does not address freedoms that existed under EU rules and one side or the other leaving the EU is not a breach of the agreement….these freedoms were assumed but not guaranteed within the agreement.

I think the problem is that the Good Friday Agreement assumes that both sides are in the EU and subject to EU law and regulation but it is not explicitly stated but is built on that assumption. Therefore there is no legal basis within the agreement to require either side to remain in the EU or apply EU law or regulations.
One could argue that some elements of strand two cooperation is not possible under EU rules if one party is in the EU and one party not in the EU. Item 8 in the annex does refer to EU programs… One can argue that strand three section 5 requires brexit, as it applies to Northern Ireland, to be handled by the British Irish council…. One can argue….
The truth is no one anticipated either side leaving the EU so issues that maybe, with hindsight, should have been included, those partaining to an open border and the free movement that EU membership brings, were assumed and not included.
One can argue that as soon as Britain introduces any North/South controls they are in breach of the agreement, but the same would hold true if the South implemented EU border controls… It is a mess

Arlene’s objective is that of the Orange Order which is to break up the Good Friday Agreement thereby precluding the possibility of a Unification Referendum and to retain the British Union. So despite what posters may say about her seeming confusion, may I respectfully suggest that it is the posters who are confused.
The DUP has already stymied the Stormont Government because its continuation would be awkward during the Brexit negotiations and instead concentrated on its privileged position of power in Westminster. As such Arlene & Co are calling the shots.
“13. It is understood that the North/South Ministerial Council and the Northern Ireland Assembly are mutually inter-dependent, and that one cannot successfully function without the other. (Source The Good Friday Agreement)
With no NI Ministers, there is no opportunity for the Ministers Republic to meet with their
NI counterparts twice a year as required by the Good Friday Agreement.
Furthermore , post Brexit , there will be no opportunity for disputes arising from the Good Friday Agreement to be resolved in the European Court again creating another out
for the DUP & the Orange Order and arguably rendering the Good Friday null & void.
So in summary, IMO, for the Good Friday Agreement to hold, NI has to remain in the EC
and subject to EC laws & regulations as contained in the Good Friday Agreement itself
apart from any subsequent Border arrangements.

Countries should have the right to protect their borders and that includes mass immigrations.
The UK has undergone massive immigration since WW2 due to the break-up of the Empire and Ireland’s inability for provide a decent standard of living for its citizens.
In our downland in the 50s-60s, out of 43 teenagers/20 somethings, 31 emigrated and
the bulk of those went to England and that is only one townland of 11 households.
Project that to the county and then on to the country and you’ll get a idea of the mass exodus of the 50′s-60s.
Ireland’s EU obligations to take East Europeans has already put strain on our sense of identity and locals competing for low paid jobs with immigrants are also likely to rebel against the EU; similar to that of the middle England working class who tilted the Brexit scales.
There is also animosity towards the country by expats who had to emigrate due to the demise of the Celtic Tiger but are now disenfranchised while recent immigrants can vote.This certainly degrades the value of citizenship and encourages immigrants to dump their Irish citizenship altogether.
For example, I live in Ireland 4 months a year in retirement , own an Irish home and car which I’m not allowed to drive because I do not qualify for an Irish driving licence* yet a Rumanian or a Lithuanian arriving off the plane can buy a car , insure it and drive it away from the airport if he or she has the lollies. What has the country come to at all!
* All 15 Irish car insurers will not offer a car insurance quote because I do not have an Irish or EU driving licence. The Irish Driving Licence Authority has refused my application for an Irish driving licence because I don’t live here more than 6 months a year.

Irish on both sides enjoy free trade and no border hassles. I visit the north occasionally
to shop and as a tourist and the only visible signs of entering the UK are:
-MPH & Miles signs vs KPH & Klm signs
-a white line on the left margin of the road
-a beep from my phone saying that I am in the UK
-Pound Sterling in the shops.

Plus, the PSNI & Gardai would need to be posted to protect them, backed by Army cover on both sides, the capacity for which is also unlikely, & no politician is likely to risk that regression in any event, even if considered possible. What is likely is administrative control of cross border trade, by prior licensing, on line recording, & auditing of legitimate trade, with normal policing of smuggling.

How about the compromise to replace the back stop is that Northern Ireland (and them alone) get to vote whether to stay in the customs union and single market or not, when the trade deal is agreed (or not) at the end of the transition period.

@Pat O Neill: You have hit upon the truly great irony in this entire fustercluck. As it stands it’s highly unlikely a Border Poll in the North would result in a United Ireland. This same would follow in the event that a Border Poll was conducted as part of a negotiated solution to the backstop – which is, as you say, entirely plausible but would still mean they have to accept a Withdrawal Deal first to allow for said negotiation.
This is exactly the sort of arrangement the DUP should have been looking for because it would solidify their hold for a generation. However, if a Border Poll happens as the result of a Hard Brexit, which all data shows will likely hurt NI most of all, their chance to win is seriously in doubt as moderate voters weigh the social and economic cost of Union with Britain. Exactly the sort of thing the DUP should literally never want them to be thinking about but then I guess fundamentalists are rarely long term thinkers.

The problem is that the British government agreed to the backstop in December 2017 and, therefore a no deal exit should see Northern Ireland remain in the Customs Union….. . and therefore there would be no hard border in the event of a no deal Brexit….. now the problem is that the British government are backtracking on the “backstop” agreed in 2017 when talks commenced…. but the official position of the Irish Government must remain that the “backstop” agreed in 2017 will be implemented by the British Government and, post Brexit, take the British government to task if they fail to implement that agreed backstop.
Of course we know that it is unlikely or impossible for the British government to implement the backstop they agreed to…. but let us deal with that when they fail to…. not in advance, and thereby giving them a “way out”.

Why?

The reunification of Ireland has been both a dream and seen as an attainable and positive objective by generations of Irish people since the country was divided in 1921 by the Government of Ireland Act, 1920 — an Act which was not drawn up and passed by the Irish people, but by the British government and the House of Commons in London.
That Act was intended to establish separate “Home Rule” (or devolved) institutions within two new divisions of Ireland: the six north-eastern counties were to form “Northern Ireland”, while the larger part of the country was to form “Southern Ireland”. Both areas of Ireland were to continue as a part of the UK, but provision was made for their future reunification under common Home Rule institutions.
“Southern Ireland” was defined as all of Ireland except for “the parliamentary counties of Antrim, Armagh, Down, Fermanagh, Derry and Tyrone, and the parliamentary boroughs of Belfast and Londonderry” which were to constitute “Northern Ireland”. These six counties (out of the nine counties of Ulster), were the maximum area within which Unionists could be expected to have a safe majority. This was in spite of the fact that counties Fermanagh, Tyrone, and parts of Derry and Armagh had large Nationalist majorities, which within a few years found themselves partly isolated inside “the border”, and under Unionist control.
The 1920 Act established the post of the “Lord Lieutenant of Ireland”, who would be the British Monarch’s representative in both parts of the divided Ireland; executive authority was to be vested exclusively in the “crown”, and not answerable to either of the two proposed parliaments, north or south. The Lord Lieutenant would appoint a cabinet that did not need parliamentary support, and there was no provision for a prime minister. This system of governance was based purely on the practice of British colonial administration, and gave no voice to the people of colonised nations.
When the Government of Ireland Act, 1920, became law on 23 December 1920 it was already out of touch with realities in Ireland. The long-standing demand for home rule had been replaced among Nationalists throughout the entire country by a strong demand for complete independence, and a War of Independence was launched and waged against British rule, which reached its lowest point in late 1920 and in 1921, when 50,000 members of the British Army, supplemented by 15,000 “special forces” and “auxiliaries” failed to quell the unrest, and could not defeat the Irish Republican Army, though the latter had probably no more than 3,000 members and was becoming short of arms and ammunition.
What followed was a treaty between Britain and the newly independent “Irish Free State”; the treaty led to a civil war in the 26 counties, there were riots and civil unrest in Belfast and Derry, followed by the expulsion of many thousands of nationalists from the six north-eastern counties, further unrest in the “North” in the 1960s, a civil rights movement in the North, followed by a violent response from the Northern administration based in Stormont near Belfast, leading to the re-emergence of the Irish Republican Army in the early 1970s, and the “armed struggle” which continued until 1994.
The Unionists in the north-east also played an important role in the division of Ireland — importing arms from Germany in 1914 (as Britain was about the declare war on Germany), declaring that they would fight by whatever methods were considered necessary in order to frustrate Britain’s intention to give “home rule” to Ireland, waging what amounted to a war against nationalists in 1920 and 1921, and then establishing a system of single-party governance under which nationalists were excluded from many senior administrative posts, were deprived of voting rights, and were discriminated against when public housing was being allocated.
Some of the institutions set up under 1920 Act continued to function until they were suspended by the British parliament in 1972 (when the Northern Ireland Act 1972 re-introduced direct rule by London from 30 March 1972), while the remaining provisions of the Act still in force in the six north-eastern counties were repealed under the terms of the 1998 Good Friday Agreement.
It is hard to believe that some provisions of the British Government’s 1920 Act were not repealed in Ireland until the Statute Law Revision Act 2007.
This brief account is only part of the story of the tangled web of relations between Britain and Ireland; in some ways similar to the relations between Lithuania, Poland and the former Soviet Union. Both Lithuania and Ireland had their distinct struggles before gaining full independence; but while Lithuania has emerged with a national territory similar to that demarcated in 1918 and has retained her ancient and rich language, Ireland has been divided, and regaining full use of our language in daily life and in government institutions is still an ideal for many …
Some parts of the story of Ireland’s independence movement are excellently documented in the superb 3-part series “The Irish Revolution”, written and directed by Ruán Magan, with input from many distinguished historians, and from participants and eye-witnesses; and based on the book “Atlas of the Irish Revolution” by John Crowley and Donal O Drisceoil (winner of the Bord Gáis Energy Book of the Year award in 2017).
The series has just concluded its first showing on RTÉ TV very recently, and you can watch on RTÉ player. https://www.rte.ie/…/the-irish-revolution/SI0000004888…
Ruán Magan also tells the story of how the documentary was made: https://www.rte.ie/…/1027632-the-irish-revolution-how…/

If the Withdrawal Agreement negotiated by the British government fails to be approved by the British parliament, the real culprit will be Jeremy Corbyn.
Corbyn’s opposition is not based on principle (his positions on the EU have flip-flopped several times over his career), it is based on his sole goal of trying to precipitate a general election in the hope that he might enter number 10 Downing Street. The Conservatives, however, will not call a general election if they think it would lead to a Corbyn government (irregardless of Brexit).
It is fashionable in the media to blame very pro-Brexit Conservative backbenchers for Mrs May’s likely-looking failure to get her deal approved, but it is not really fair to blame them because they are actually acting on principle. Brexiteer backbenchers want a genuine Brexit – as per the referendum question (“Leave or Remain”) in the 2016 public vote – not a half-in-half-out fudge as per May’s Withdrawal Agreement.
The British Labour Party are supposedly in favour of the UK remaining in the customs union, and yet they won’t take the opportunity to approve the deal (endorsed by the Irish Government and the rest of the EU) which effectively ensures that Britain remains in the EU’s customs union. The reason why the Labour Party won’t play ball is because of Jeremy Corbyn’s politicking and intellectual dishonesty.
The Irish Government must be blamed for doing a terrible job in terms of lobbying the UK Labour Party to support this Withdrawal Agreement. Varadkar’s government has been utterly remiss in this regard. The Irish Government, and media, have fruitlessly concentrated their attacks on Conservative backbenchers who were always going to be unmoved by such tactics. The Irish Government, political parties and Irish media should have worked much harder in trying to convince the British Labour Party to support the Withdrawal Agreement. If tonight’s vote fails, it will be because the Labour Party didn’t support it even though the deal was endorsed by Ireland and the rest of the European Union.

Motions in parliament are not legally binding on the UK government. The only thing that matters is statute, and the statute that is relevant to Brexit is the EU Withdrawal Act which was passed in 2018. That piece of primary legislation (which is the most powerful type of legislation) requires that the UK leaves the European Union on March 29th with or without a deal. The only person who can initiate primary legislation (which is what would be needed to override the EU Withdrawal Act) is the prime minister herself/himself. So, it is really up to Theresa May herself as to whether she wants to undermine Brexit, and subvert the will of her electorate, by delaying her country’s exit from the European Union.

That surprising. Trucks from Ireland should be transiting UK under TIR 1975 Convention ie customs sealed and not opened from loading up in Ireland until they arrive at their continental destination. Unless there is some suspicion by UK customs that there is something irregular going on. I’ve even seen a suggestion that Irl TIR trucks would get loading priority onto Ferries since they won’t pitentially delay the departures – that’s just hearsay, though.

@Pat O’Leary: before our open borders, the express bus to Donegal had its boot sealed at the Cavan/Fermanagh border customs post. Passengers boarding in Enniskillen (the only NI stop back then) had to take their luggage inside the bus. The boot remained sealed until customs at Belleek, on the Donegal/Fermanagh border, halted the bus to check the luggage of Enniskillen passengers and unseal the boot. In the days when trains from ROI passed through NI to Donegal, passenger carriages were also sealed by customs. So it won’t be hard to seal and unseal lorry loads of inanimate goods. Our customs have done it before.

Not sure about the rest of us, but landlords in rent pressure zones are guaranteed a minimum 4% per year. And the sky is the limit outside of the zones. And FFG clapped themselves on the back for it??
@Fr. Fintan Stack: you know that’s turn over/revenue, not salary? Two totally different things. But hey, any excuse to stamp on landlords should be availed of

@Ciaran Whyte: It doesn’t matter to the tenant if its turnover or whatever, its still 4% rise and that’s 4% after tax, PRSI, USC etc. So for a tenant on 35,300 euro a year he/she has to have an 8% pay rise per year just to keep up with a 4% rent rise. Thats 24-32% over the next 3/4 years. Ordinary workers don’t have the allowances landlords have.
The figures suggest that a landlord with income of €1,500 a month, or €18,000 a year, would have claimed deductions of about €7,380 against this income, leaving taxable income of €10,620. This income is then liable to income tax, at either 20 per cent or 40 per cent, PRSI and USC. But I don’t know of any landlords with income that low, so multiply that.

@Eddie Mc Keown: Crown Colonies were renamed British Overseas Territories following the royal assent of the British Overseas Territories Act 2002. So their colonies are supposed to be called British Overseas Territories. Though Tony Blare called them “colonies” about 2 days after the Act was passed:
“Gibraltar’s parliament approved an ambitious package of constitutional reform yesterday designed to give the colony almost complete self-government.” – Tony Blare, 28 February 2002.
Previously to the 26th February 2002, most British Overseas Territories Citizens (BOTCs) were not accorded nor could they automatically apply for full British citizenship (exceptions were BOTCs on Gibraltar and the Falkland Islands). After this date, all BOTCs automatically qualified for British Citizenship. Additionally, BOTCs born after the 26th February 2002 can easily apply for British citizenship which is almost always grated except in cases where the applicant fails on bad character grounds.
The act also effectively granted all BOTCs EU citizenship, which they will loose after the UK leaves the EU.
Ironically, it an be argued British Overseas Territories are now even more appropriately called colonies, as a colony is defined as “a territory under the immediate complete political control and occupied by settlers of a state, distinct from the home territory of the sovereign.” and yes, they have British on them, whereas previously people weren’t always British citzens but e.g. Bermudan, Montserratian, Anguillian etc.
But on the other hand, they are not British settlers from Great Britain, indeed some places like Montserrat are inhabited predominately by former African Slaves and descendants of Irish indentured servants (a euphemism for slaves) who didn’t want to go there, they weren’t willing settlers.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories_Act_2002

From March 30th the UK can import any goods they need or want from the EU and charge duty or not as they see fit.
EXPORTS from the UK to the EU are quite a different matter.

UK exports to the EU STOPS on March 30th.
Australia, New Zealand, Brazil, Argentina ECT. Have quotas to export lamb, beef ECT. On which we pay duty.

The thing is…..the government says it does not want a hard border, the EU and the UK say the same, so why on earth should planning take place for one?
If there is to be one then please let others try to impose a hard border on us rather than defeatist planning in expectation on our behalf. That, at least, would encourage resistance on our part.
This is a clearly defined Atlantic island, not Alsace-Lorraine or some other nebulously defined place with a fluid and disputed border that changes with military or political upheavals.
The rosy benefits of being in the EU would pale into insignificance if the EU and/or UK re-establish a border between people that have slowly, very slowly, begun to successfully reconcile the past with contemporary realities.
Under absolutely no circumstances should the Dublin administration become involved with securing or administering the re-establishment of a UK or EU dictated border across our island.

Ireland on the other hand would suffer all the negatives of being a third country while still a member of the EU in theory, just not in practice.
We have always been at a disadvantage by virtue of being an Island nation, separate from the rest of Europe with the extra burden of ferry transport of goods and physical detachment from markets and supply chains.
An external EU border is by definition hard, ending up on the outside of it is something we haven’t chosen and a burden we shouldn’t be forced into, by or to suit anyone.

The Oireachtas should not pass legislation allowing Norther Ireland-registered vessels to fish in Republic of Ireland waters. Even if the UK were ultimately to ban Republic-registered vessels from fishing in N.I. waters in response, Northern Irish fishermen would still have more to lose.
This issue is not about a bargaining chip for Brexit. It’s about something much more important than that. The fact that there are separate fishing jurisdictions, around the island of Ireland, shows the madness of the partition that the British insisted upon in 1921. The Irish government should use the Supreme Court’s decision on this fishing matter, handed down two years ago, as a further argument for the re-unification of Ireland as a sovereign state. We should not extend fishing rights to Northern Irish vessels until partition is ended, once and for all. Giving away our fishing rights would be a surrender of yet another bargaining chip for re-unification.

Will UK citizens be asked to pay for residents permits if they live in Spain, or France or Germany?
I see over in Belgium, any UK citizens resident there will have to exchange their UK driving licences for a Belgian one, or do a Belgian driving test… So when they go to the UK, can they drive on an EU/Belgiant licence?
This is just one bit of red tape in one of the 27 EU countries, not gonna be an easy road for UK citizens abroad.

@Dotty Dunleary: Exchange of a non EU licence for a licence in an EU member state is a matter for each EU member individually. For example Spain will exchange many South American countries but Ireland will not. That is the situation for people who take up residency in the EU. However driving on a foreign licence when visiting for holidays is governed by 3 U.N. traffic conventions, unless superseded by a direct agreement between the countries. That is why we have an international drivers permit. So in short how you use your drivers licence when you go on holidays when you go outside the EU is nothing got to do with the EU. Brexit will not change this because it is a UN convention that governs it.

@John Horan: individual agreements. Same with Canadian Provinces they needed to have individual agreements with Ireland for straight swap of driving licenses up until recently you had to sit a driving test again to get one.

Simple solution to all of this: Single Transferrable Vote.
No one proposal is more than 50% popular, so MP’s are left second-guessing if voting down an option in the centre is going to result in giving momentum to the left or right. STV sorts all that out, immediately identifies the non-runners instead of giving hopeless options oxygen, allows voters to rank their preferences, and settles on whichever option can get at least some degree of approval from over half the voting population.
@Michael Doyle: only there is no STV in the UK parliament or electoral system. All votes in UK parliament are binary.

@Michael Doyle:
They had a referendum on that in 2011, defeated by a big margin.

Next problem is how to vote for suitable candidates for parliament.to represent you. First-past-the-post election results in strategic voting and limited options for voters. A General Election result can be very unrepresentative of public preferences, in that Labour could get a huge majority with 35 percent of the vote, so long as the other 65 is split among multiple candidates, several of whom maybe would have won in a head to head.
Solution: Again, STV. Have as many candidates as you want, let the public genuinely vote based on preference, automatically eliminate the also-rans and automatically see who gets a 50 percent-plus acceptance on a head-to-head basis.

All that said, the future is worrying as heretofore we had an Ireland UK border and we may have an EU rest of world border in the future which is a whole different beast with different, international, responsibilities on both sides, particularly if the UK makes trade deal which are incompatible with EU trade deals.

A small majority of British people voted in favour of leaving (c 52% v 48%) because they were fed up with European Laws and Regulations – 1) interfering with their own preference of interpretation of their country’s laws; 2) allowing people of the other 27 EU countries to have freedom to live and work in the UK (forgetting the vice versa freedom-to-travel allowance); 3) making them pay VAT and other contributions into the EU-governing ‘Exchequer’ coffers from which many sectors of its population receive, in return, EU grants and 4) being wrongly led to believe that not being part of the EU would divert VAT etc funds back into their crumbling NHS.
The truths are out now.
Despite the UK’s Brexit Referendum statistics showing that majorities voting to Remain were, very specially in London (the most populous area of the UK), in Scotland, Nth Ireland, West Wales and that the vote to ‘Leave’ was carried by a disparate conglomerate of ‘rural’ villages, towns and smaller cities of Britain. These are locations of the veritable falsely-led believers in ‘Britannia Rules…’
(There was at least one suggestion that London City and its Greater Area should declare to be an independent state to preserve its massive ties to the EU. It is also notable that the effect of Brexit on Gibraltar, and all the UK’s other minion dominion islands around the world, have not been considered in sufficient depth or publicised enough).
Now that reality is biting hard that the VAT/NHS falsities has long been disproved, a 2nd referendum is very definitely worth a call. Let the people decide with their second, more-educated and reflective thoughts – and that the UK’s Parliament should not have a ‘final say’ over their 2nd vote.
Personally, I would not like the UK to leave the EU and would hope talk of a ‘Deal’ or ‘No Deal’ be taken off all negotiation agenda.
However, I do believe there is a way out… Forget about any ‘Deal’ or ‘No-deal’, wipe them off the table. Start with a clean slate. Future negotiations could perhaps include addressing the concerns of British people and EU laws to be changed to accommodate – not just theirs – but other populist nationalism concerns facing the EU within its own other 27 countries e.g. Italy, Austria, Greece and even Ireland.
If the EU can make laws, they can change or adapt them to make all member countries happy to live in unifying consensus.

The UK will leave. It is just that none of us know yet how that is going to look. I don’t think it will leave properly until for another 5-10 years. It will then form a space for itself in the wider world, but form a space it will. Too many of us in Ireland have gone again into a default position whether it’s Brit slagging or genuine concern over Ireland’s position.
Whether it is trade or general cultural links with the UK, these are enormous. The shift in how we work with the UK over that 5/10-year period will be the focus and increasingly so.
My big concern will be also during that time how the EU tax harmonisation and wider closer, we could call it federal partnership, develops. It will be a time for us to finally have a debate as to what we want as a country out of this. That discussion hasn’t even started. There seems to be an ‘official’ Ireland view, that of the two main political parties and a largely compliant media, that EU membership is the only way forward but like a lot of the smaller EU countries, what is that partnership going to be, and how close or not it should be. The UK’s decision will leave this issue as one of the defining areas to be dealt with by Ireland over the course of the next decade.
I believe more Euroscepticism will develop here. I’m just not sure yet whether this will remain a relatively small level of concern about where the EU is going, or whether the percentages of disagreement will increase, that the trend that has appeared across mainland Europe will take route here. As a nation our views on Europe have actually proved to be rather fickle. It might not take much to happen for it to sway towards higher level of concerns. This will be set against an ‘official’ Ireland/media continuously be pro EU. Will be fascinating to see how this develops and even more so, which politicians and parties will manage this process over coming years, and fully tap into public opinion.

I wonder does President Macron realise that he is stirring up the old frisson that les Anglais have in regard to French culture and revolutionary nationhood? France has always welcomed political and religious refugees into its metropolitan society, something admirable. Nevertheless, the French sense of nationhood has always been strong from Jeanne d’Arc onwards and even more so since the French Revolution, the Napoleonic wars, the amazing industrial revolution and the expansion of the French empire. France has been strongly European – on French terms not on Brussels terms. Geographically France and Germany are in the heart of Western Europe and economically they have the ability to drive European economic development. English society knows this and wishes to deal with continental Europe on its own terms. The EU project for a United States of Europe has been stalled by the Dutch and French referendum rejections of the proposed EU constitution. The UK withdrawal from the EU represents an English nationalist separation from the Franco-German United Europe steering engine. It is a contradiction for a French leader to criticize nationalism when his own country has exemplified the concept of a liberation nationalism that inspired slave revolts in the Caribbean, liberation movements in South America (Simon Bolivar & Bernardo O’Higgins), Irish nationalism and movements in Poland and elsewhere during the turbulent 19th century. The EU has achieved economic & infrastructural innovation among its 27 disparate members. Free trade and free movement of people is something to be grateful for. Education and cultural co-operation such as the Erasmus programme is important for international understanding. But I doubt whether a sense of EU common nationality is possible or desirable. Instead, a sense of common pan-European cultural identity may be achievable – even if Western European societies have been busy in recent decades shedding some of western civilization’s inherited traits.

Backstop may threaten Northern Irish human rights, says Cox
Cox said unless the backstop could be shown to be a temporary arrangement, it risked breaching protocol 1, article 3 of the convention, which protects the rights of people to vote in order to choose their legislature.
In what appeared to be a curve ball, Cox told the EU that Northern Irish citizens would be unrepresented in the EU’s decision-making institutions, including the European parliament, thereby diminishing their rights.
“The attorney general said there was a risk of violating the ECHR,” a senior EU source said. “He said a lot of surprising things this week.”

One factor that is being overlooked in the post no deal brexit reality is, it’s not only perishable goods with days or a week of shelf life that are at risk.
If a truck leaves Ireland with a refrigerated trailer that is carrying a cargo that has a 1- 6 month self life like pharmaceuticals or some food stuffs and it needs to be kept at less than 5° Celsius the trailer refrigeration unit runs intermittently and has approximately 4 days worth of diesel to run it, if the truck is held in motorway tailbacks or in a containment lot while processing through checks that involve every other truck and cargo transiting the UK, they won’t be able to keep them running, blast frozen goods would have even less run time because at -20 they run almost constantly.
